description: From Middle English entreten, from Anglo-Norman entretier, from Old French entraiter, from en- + traiter.

examples: Let my entreats of Love prevail so far, / When for your happinesse they spoken are:  [â€¦]

verbs.description: entreat (third-person singular simple present entreats, present participle entreating, simple past and past participle entreated)

entries.meaning: To treat with, or in respect to, a thing desired; hence, to ask for earnestly.
To beseech or supplicate (a person); to prevail upon by prayer or solicitation; to try to persuade.
examples: It were a fruitless attempt to appease a power whom no prayers could entreat.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To treat or discourse; hence, to enter into negotiations, as for a treaty.
examples: of which I shall have further occasion to intreate

entries.meaning: (obsolete, intransitive) To make an earnest petition or request.
(obsolete, transitive) To treat, or conduct toward; to deal with; to use.
